verb.description: Lightly touch or prod (a person or a part of the body) in a way that causes itching and often laughter.
examples: she tickled me under the chin

verb.description: Appeal to (someone's taste, sense of humor, curiosity, etc.)
examples: here are a couple of anecdotes that might tickle your fancy
Dad gave my chin a little tickle

phrases: The few articles I saw, in my comings and goings, were so good that I was tickled pink to have had them under my name.
Jenna was tickled pink that Amanda would take the time to make her look good in front of her neighbours.
I know he would have been tickled pink, a little embarrassed and mightily amused.
Melanie was tickled pink when she saw his picture.
I'd be tickled pink to run it.
origin: Middle English (in the sense be delighted or thrilled): perhaps a frequentative of tick, or an alteration of Scots and dialect kittle to tickle (compare with kittle).
